question.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding sex determination in animals?

options.text: Grasshoppers, male = autosomes  <math><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> , female = autosomes  <math><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>

Drosophila, males = autosomes  <math><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> , female = autosomes  <math><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>

Birds, females = autosomes  <math><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi></math> , males = autosomes  <math><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math>
Insects (XO type), all sperms = one set of autosomes <math><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>

solution.text: In some insects which show XO type of sex determination female carries autosomes and XX chromosomes and male carries autosomes and XO (single X chromosome) , i.e. male has 1 chromosome less than female. Example - Grasshopper (female carries 34 chromosomes and male carries 33 chromosomes) . In males 50% sperms carry one set of autosomes and one X chromosome, while remaining 50% sperms carry only one set of autosomes but no sex chromosome.
